Since the foregoingTC to JN, 5 Oct., enclosed as “No 1.“ was written, Gilchrist comes in with tidings abt Weimar Marshall’sJames Marshall. proposed Copy of the Retrospective Review.The Retrospective Review, ed. H. Southern and N. H. Nicolas, 16 vols. (1820–28); two further vols. were pbd. 1853–54. The vols. contained a wide variety of articles on historical figures. The Book, it seems, is very scarce, and costs from £6 to £8, the whole 16 volumes of it. Gilchrist has picked up one copy, imperfect, but capable of being supplemented by two odd volumes discovered elsewhere, so that it shall want only 1 vol., the last,—at the cheap rate of £2..18 in all. This, I concluded, wd be Marshall’s fit; so instructed Gilcht to buy it at once, and pay down 10 / of the
price (6 / for the two odd voll. $PL4 / towards that of the other 13 voll.), which he will no doubt do this day. He is to bring the 2 odd voll to the Shop where the 13 are (shop indicated in Note enclosed);Untraced. and there you will find the whole 15,—£2..8 still to pay upon them;—and will only farther have to mention my name in order to get hold of them. It is I that paid the 10 /:—I will pay the remainder, if young Foman (?),Presumably an employee of Williams & Norgate, otherwise unidentified. who was to spediren [dispatch] from Wms & Norgate’s, has not the cash also ready. Pray despatch that thing too; and let us hear on Sunday night that it is all off our hands.— Yours always

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Neuberg has made notes of place names from the map “Journey to the Reich“ (see Works 13:opp. 312) on the back of the letter.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JGC [JGCO], [6 Oct.]. MS: NLS 606.513. Pbd: Froude, LM 2:387–88; Hansons, NE 476 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN GEORGE COOKE

docBody.p: Dear Mr Cook—I am here again—the more’s the pity! Once for all this London atmosphere weighs on me, I find, like a hundred weight of lead! no health no spirits one brings from “the Country“ can bear up against it! Come and console me! at least come and try “to!“ on Sunday afternoon perhaps? Mr C is home from his battlefields and as busy and private as before! So my evenings are now sacred to reading on his part, and mortally ennuying myself on mine!

“Quoth Burgundy the Living, / On Earth, have much to bear.“Coterie speech; see 24:51JWC to JW, [17 May 1849]. TC has written on the blank facing page: “Said Burgundy, ‘I’m giving / Much toil to thee, I fear:’ / Eckart replied, ‘The living / On Earth have much to bear.’ / (Tieck’s Phantasms; / the Trusty Eckart of my translating!)“; see Works 21:299. Ludwig Tieck (1773–1853), German romantic writer.

p.name: Jane W Carlyle
p.note: TC has written beneath the signature: “(return from 2d German Tour).“

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 6 Oct. Addr: 2 St John’s Villas / Highbury Vale. PM: 7 Oct. 1858. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p:
Dear Sir,—They are going to print the Friedh again,—to begin quite immediately, both volumes at once, it appears. Pray let me have the those sheets
again, therefore; you may call at Robson’s, and get the fractions that were wanting, the Tables of Contents &c &c; so that I may have it all before me, and get it sent to Rn fairly off my hands. If you know any errors, of course now is the time.—— In regard to Bosworth’sProbably Thomas Bosworth ca. (1823–99), of Bosworth & Harrison, booksellers and publishers, 215 Regent St.; see 23:101TC to EC, 31 Aug. 1848. Ink, please merely to order it and pay the shilling. Bth, if you charge him, will himself send it hither without delay.— In haste as ever!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JB [JBA], 11 Oct. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES BALLANTINE

docBody.p: You are very kind, and offer me a conspicuous place among my fellow creatures, on an Occasion which may well interest Scotchmen and others. You may believe me, you and all my Edinburgh friends, I am not insensible to this honour: but the sad truth is, I cannot come. Weak health, heavy disproportionate pressure of confused business:—for these, and for other good reasons that could be given if these were not enough, I must deny myself the professed pleasure, and answer, No with many thanks and regrets.TC’s “many thanks and regrets“ are not included in James Ballantine, ed., Chronicle of the Hundredth Birthday of Robert Burns (Edinburgh, 1859).
I pray you accept these feelings, which are very real on my part; and believe me now as always
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: James Ballantine Esq &c &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 11 Oct. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 12 Oct. 1858. MS: NLS 552.175. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
I cannot find the place where that culpable definition of “the Reich“:TC is writing about corrections to the first two vols. of Frederick but the definition is untraced. The Reich or Holy Roman Empire is mentioned several times in vol. 1; see Works 12:56–58, 72, 106, 108–12, and 117–23. See also TC to JN, 20 Oct. do you know where? If a little change could be admitted whh wd mend it, I should like;—shd like to try at any rate. But after all it is a fact of no interest,
importance, or almost meaning, to the English reader of Frh’s History,—to confuse whom with commentary on such a point wd be a worse error perhaps than what is already written amiss. If you know the place name it; if not, never mind it farther.

I find in Map II (the only I have yet looked at) a good many other misprints of Names; these must be rectified: I think of getting from Mr Larkin a copy of the 2 mapsSee TC to HL, 13 Oct. to send them to you as Proofsheet.

Does your German NeighbourUnidentified. know of a certainty, what the plural of Profos [Provost] (or Profoss, which is right?)Profoss; the plural is Profossen. ought to be? I suspected the Profösse (Vol I, p. 421) was wrong, when suggested to me; but had to let it pass in the hurry. Tell me now, if you can possibly ascertain beyond dispute.
I forgot the Marshall Money;James Marshall; see TC to JN, 6 Oct. but not for long! Do not delay writing a short word to him.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-EC, 12 Oct. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD CHAPMAN

docBody.p: I do not myself see anything to hinder your third Thousand as proposed.Of Frederick. But you had better write to Forster upon it; Forster, I suppose, will have to be at the settling about these new finance questions as before,—and I am far too busy for thinking abt them just now.

I have written to Robson, earnestly requesting despatch; and indicating “two months“ as my own guess. The Copy is as plain as daylight,—now all ready for him, or on the point of that;—and I do not mean to look at any sheet farther. “Two months,“ however, is almost 2 sheets a-day, is it not? To “put out a volume,“ with Robson correcting, might possibly do; otherwise it wd be dangerous!—
There are some words wrong-spelt in the maps; item every map ought to have upon it vol & page (p.—a), that the Binder may not be able to blunder. Larkin will see to that, in time.

The Engraving to Vol II too,The frontispiece of vol. 2 was an engraving of Pesne’s portrait of Friedrich Wilhelm; see Works 13:frontispiece I suppose, is irremediable? It has not the least trace of Frh Wm’s physiognomy in it,—whh must be admitted to be a
grave defect! Two more sordidly mechanical pieces of “Art“The frontispiece of vol. 1 was Francis Holl’s engraving of Pesne’s The Little Drummer; see 33:116TC to EC, 13 Nov. 1857 I have not seen lately:—surely there is better to be got in London than that. If not, I think we must try Berlin or some other quarter, next time.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 13 Oct. MS: NLS 516.59 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Sister,—I am disappointed not to have heard of your new BooksCopies of Frederick. (to Dumfries, Scotsbrig &c) having in the least arrived yet! Copies of the new Book were duly sent, to all the kindred yet left, as in old cases;—and I conclude they are all lying in Edinr (much at their ease, in the hands of one Menzies a Bookseller,John Menzies, 61 Princes St., Edinburgh. who is Chapman’s Co-agent there), quietly waiting “an opportunity“!— Yesterday, Jane went to the said Chapman; made him instantly poke up the Menzies; who will now proceed by railway:—and in short if the [MS cut away]The MS is the top part of a page; the bottom has been cut away. in fact looks every way promising. I am heartily glad at this fine change in the poor lad’s positn and outlooks:Jean’s son James, who had begun work as a clerk in London. I see a fair chance for him of doing altogether handsomely henceforth,—good honest quiet lad as he is. We put him in a Brompton Omnibus last night; and he sailed away homeward as if quite native to it.

Jane is not fairly failing yet; but I much dread this cold damp weather: fierce northwind one time, then muddy s. west (as today) another.— — I am not “improving“ much, myself; so tumbled about, incessantly in confusion; and even my Horse only half yet in a riding condition. I go upon him every second day,—nothing like so fast yet as wd altogether content me
[incomplete]

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 13 Oct. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Wd you come to me, as soon as you like, and bring a Copy of the First Two maps (Baireuth,Frederick, 1st edn., 1:opp. 300, and Works 12:opp. 252. Journey to ReichFrederick, 1st edn., 2:opp. 258, and Works 13:opp. 312.),—of the Third (Pra)Kingdom of Prussia; see Frederick, 1st edn., 2:opp. 694, and Works 14: after 413. I always have a Copy:—there is some little thing to be done with them still.

Bosworth has never sent his ink:—perhaps he wd be so kind as tell you where the real place for it is, so that we might go direct in quest of it? Don’t stop about that. This is baddish ink; but I make it do.— Robson and the map question are what concern us.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Chelsea, Wedy, 13 Octr (?)Wed. was 13 Oct. 1858—

div3.sourceNote: TC-ÉM [EM], 15 Oct. Pbd: P. A. Meunier, “Lettres Inédites,“ Revue de Littérature Comparée 5 (1925): 503.
div3.head: TC TO ÉMILE MONTÉGUT

docBody.p: Owing to perverse accidents, the foolish blame of which is my own chiefly, I have not fairly got your letter till this morning! I beg you excuse my seeming neglects.As to the Frederick, unluckily (in one sense) there is not a copy of it left, for some time past. The edition went away “in a week“—the bookseller reports—and not till he get a second printed, which he is urging forward with all his might, can I have the pleasure of fulfilling your requestIn his undated letter, [late Sept.], (probably a reply to TC to ÉMEM, 24 Sept.), Émile Montégut thanked TC for sending him copies of the cheap edn. of TC’s Works and asked him for a copy of Frederick.—Tauchnitz’s reprint (at Leipzig), or the better part of it, I see, is already in circulation; 3 little volumes out, the other two soon coming: no doubt it is at Galignani’sEnglish lib. in Paris, est. Giovanni Antonio Galignani (1752–1821) and continued by his sons. as elsewhere; and if you are very pressing, that will be a resource.

Lewes is in Germany this good while, I know not specially where. Mr
PigottMontégut had sent copies of some of his essays to G. H. Lewes and Edward F. S. Pigott (1824–95), journalist, and he hoped that they had arrived safely. Lewes had been in Germany but returned to London 2 Sept. I do not personally know, nor anything about The trader,A mistranscription for The Leader, started by Lewes and Thornton Hunt (1810–73; ODNB) (see 25:72–73TC to JCA, 25 [26] April 1850) and owned by Pigott since 1851. in late times, but I will take the earliest opportunity of sending your message in some sure way. The sea-shore is solacing and wholesome to nervous people, physically, morally: one of my own vain dreams has always been that of getting to reside in some solitary place, within sound of its everlasting voice and in the sphere of its grand busities. Could not you contrive more frequently to get back thither, and carry on your work there?Montégut had just returned from Normandy, where he had spent three months in search of leisure and health, but his health had not improved.

I have still lying ahead a mass of dreary chaotic labour, which, in my now state of bodily strenghtThus in printed source. and spiritual, is enough to make me shudder! I mean to get thro’ it, if I can, and then rest forever.
Your EssaysMontégut had sent TC his Essais sur l’époque actuelle; see TC to ÉM, 24 Sept. are circulating with good acceptance; I found excellent reading in that little volume.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-AC, 15 Oct. MS: MUL. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:193–94 inc; Marrs 729–31. The MS is torn.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have meant this long while to write to you, so soon as the hurlyburly would a little abate and now I had better proceed at once than wait farther. I might have written, with more seeming composure, out of poor old native Annandale, where I was not long since: but there I always felt so sad of heart, and several things (especially poor Jane’s health here in London) were so uncertain with me, I never like to infect you with these humours. I am now home after unusual wanderings, one job (or half of a job) done, the other not begun: before beginning, I will ha[ve] a word with dear old Alick, faithful Brother Wayfarer wi[th me on this] Earth almost from my first starting,TC’s brother Alexander Carlyle was b. 4 Aug. 1797, 20 months after TC. and whose unalterable lo[ve] responded to by my own, is one of the sacred treasures I have still [left] here.

[Th]ose two V[olumes of] Frederick were by far the hardest job ever laid
upon me, even in the best of my strength; often enough I thought, within the last two years I have been pulling and toiling, that I shd never get thro’ it. I had to ride very diligently, and be canny too; or that sad prophecy might have come true! However, they are now done, those two Volumes (and people all reading them, with much noise whh I take care to hear little of);Thomas Woolner visited the Carlyles, 16 Oct., and wrote to Emily Tennyson, 22 Oct.: “Old Sir Francis is almost enthusiastic about Carlyle’s Frederick, says that [it] is by far the best thing C. has done. He generally thinks and speaks of him as a wild man“ (Woolner 154). Sir Francis Palgrave (1788–1861; ODNB), archivist and historian.—and there are still Two more to be done (perhaps two years of hard work, if I still live); but they are not nearly so difficult, I expect, as the former were, if I can only keep my strength so long!— — I got out of these first Two Volumes in june last, or mainly out of them, for my share: but the Bookseller did not publish them till quite lately, the beginning of this month. A Copy (two big volumes) was sent off to you, and another to Sister Jenny (according to the old rule in such cases), duly addressed, a fortnight ago. When they will get to you I cannot guess, nor by what route the Bookseller ultimately [will send] them; but upon some route they actually are; and you need not be impatient for them farther. I suppose a Yankee Copy,Pbd. by Harper & Bros.; see TC to JWC, 21 Aug. cheap, [may be] procurable, if you are too ea[ger] [letter torn] A se[ ] is also [ ] way at its fastest; the people (for the first time in their lives and mine) having made a kind of run upon my ware. Whh amou[nts] to a little prospect of money, but not of any other kind of profit or pleasure to me.— Tell Tom, too, that I have some more volumes for him;Vols. of the cheap edn. of TC’s works for Thomas, Alexander’s eldest son; see 33:26TC to AC, 13 Aug. 1857. that there is still another of his set to publish; and that so soon as it is out, I mean to despatch the whole by post as formerly.—

The instant I had got done with my part of the Task, I ran off for Annandale; end of june last;—quite worn to the [gro]und, and in very great need of rest. John, with some of his Boys, was at Scotsbrig; otherwise perhaps I had aimed thither: as it was, I made for The Gill; and continued about two months there, as idle as a dry bone; sauntering abt in strict silence, riding a little, reading a little;—peaceable, but in the natural sadness of humour all the time. Jane, whom [ ] was in very feeble state,—as she is generally, poor thing, for [ ]—and I had a great deal of writing and anxiety [ ] her; nearly all the writing I could prevail on myself to do [ ] is now fa [ . Jane] came to Scotland about the end of August (just when I was leaving; so badly had we ordered it): I now have her here safe again, a little stronger against the winter-storms that are coming. Jean came often out to me from Dumfries; three times or so I rode over to Scotsbrig for an hour or two; Dr and Jamie came [abt] as often to see me: from all the rest of the human species I was silent & withdrawn. A man at 63 has a strange feeling when visiting his native
country,—as of a ghost coming back to the Earth! I rode one day, market-day, thro’ [An]nan; did not see one soul whose face was known to me; only the old stone-walls were familiar; and strangers gazed at my “wide-awake“ hat and old grey beard,—asking, as their fathers or grandfathers would not have needed to do, “Who’s that?“— — All our kindred were rather well in Annandale, and doing well. The Railways in that Country still keep farming profitable; California Gold (that is it, I privately believe) keeps all “trade“ in a kind of [ ]. Jamie of Scotsbrig is a tight little fellow [ ] greyish as becomes that age; manages his sheep-hus[bandries] spl[ ] with evident success, and indeed is a very [ ] quietly este[emed. Here] has Jack himself come in; and it is time for me, and more than time, to be out. I will write again before so long. Ah me, Ah me!— May God bless you ever, you & yours.

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Woolner wrote that TC was “remarkably well, in excellent spirits and a good temper.“ He intended taking Rajah Brooke (James Brooke [1803–68; ODNB], 1st rajah of Sarawak) “to see the grim philosopher. … it will be good fun to see them together—the man whose pen talks strong words and the man who talks thro’ cannon-thunder and with sharp swords“ (Woolner 153–54).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [17 Oct.]. MS: NLS 553.246. Written on the reverse of Charlotte Williams Wynn to TC, 17 Oct.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: (J. Neuberg Esqr / to read & burn)

Dear Neuberg,—Will you be so kind as write, on a patch of paper, the required address;Charlotte Williams Wynn wrote that she had been “much shocked“ reading of Varnhagen von Ense’s death, 10 Oct., in the Leader: “I wish to write to his niece as soon as may be, but unfortunately know not the name of the Street in which he lived. … Berlin simply, was sufficient direction on my Letters to him, but it is too vague an address for Miss Assing.“ Ludmilla Assing (1821–80); see 33:26733:biographical note. slip it into that cover; then close, and despatch by post. I find no briefer way.Varnhagen von Ense died while playing chess with his niece in Berlin “in the presence of a large circle of persons of high rank“ (Illustrated London News, 23 Oct. 1858).

The Leuthen Dame ought to be praised for her historical piety, thanked &c;—I fear there will not of practical much come from her:“[O]ne comely gentlewoman, well-dressed, of a certain age, went and came observantly, who at length got into speech with Neuberg down below. … ‘Had her Uncle, Catholic Priest of the place, but been here.’ … Fair guide, a black-eyed tall personable woman … clearly the flower of this poor Day for us“ (Carlyle, Journey 62). Otherwise unidentified. but that too you can try.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [18? Oct.]. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Dated on a Monday soon after TC to JN, 11 Oct., where TC wrote of Neuberg’s being sent “a copy of the 2 maps … as Proofsheet.“
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Mr Neuberg has brot back the Maps: if you come up I will deliver them with my own corrections, if any.
docBody.name: T. C.

ps.p: Chelsea, Monday morng

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 20 Oct. MS: NLS 552.176. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Have I happened to lend you the Küster I brought from Weimar,—Küster’s Lebens-Errettungen Frh’s der Grossen?Carl Daniel Küster (1727–1804), Die Lebensrettungen Friedrichs des Zweyten im siebenjährigen Kriege und besonders der Hochverrath des Barons von Warkotsch, 2d edn. (Berlin, 1797). It lay for weeks on this Table; and now today the whole House has been ransacked for it in vain.— I do not the least want the Book; but want extreme-TC has omitted “ly“ in turning the page. to know where it is.

The Quark [rubbish] about “The Reich“See TC to JN, 11 Oct. I did not use, after all! Here it is, for your inspection,—and combustion. Having dressed one’s cucumber with pepper, with vinegar, with &c, a certain Receipt directs, “Then throw it out of window.“Cf. Works 15:265.— It was extremely difficult to explain, in three lines compass, to impatient English readers, How there came to be two “Reichs,“TC probably means the western Empire, which came into being when Charlemagne was crowned emperor by the pope in 800, and the eastern or Byzantine Empire of Constantine VI (770–97?). what the second “Reich“ really was, &c &c— In fine, here it is,—fairly out of window;—two words being put into the Text,The relationship between church and state, and thus pope and emperor, was a major element in the definition of the early Holy Roman Empire. TC perhaps refers to the addition to later edns. of Frederick of the phrase describing the Holy Roman emperors as “by theory a kind of ‘Deacons to the Pope,’ or something else“ (Works 12:122–23), indicating that emperors were secular rulers but had a spiritual role as well; otherwise TC’s change is untraced. to stave off the hawks from pecking at me.

The Old Dessauer also I have let stand;—“poor Varnhagen,Varnhagen von Ense, “Fürst Leopold von Anhalt-Dessau,“ Biographische Denkmale, 2d edn. (Berlin, 1845); see Works 12:25. a loose authority, referring to after times of the Dessr’s History,“ and other excuses.
“Swedish“ the like; whh is the word in all the Books,—nor did I ever hear of “Spaniards“ being in the 30-years War at all.— Enough, enough.

They are printing with all their energy; “to have done on Decr 15“Chapman & Hall advertised in the Athenaeum, 18 Dec., that the 2d edn. of Frederick was “now ready“; see 32:222Chapman & Hall’s Advertisements. (whh I do not believe);—and two insignificant corrections I sent for vol II (for they are printing in 4 or 5 difft parts of their Copy) were already too late.

I have got a Book or two for you here (“The German Spy“Thomas Lediard the Elder (1685–1743), The German Spy: In Familiar Letters. … Written by a Gentleman on His Travels, to His Friends in England (1738); see Works 13:163 (where TC misdates the book 1725). at least, if you will accept it from me) agt your next coming.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JW [JWEL], [21 or 28 Oct.]. Pbd: Huxley, LJWC 635–36. John Welsh visited JWC, as requested, some time before 30 Oct.; see JWC to MR, [30 Oct.].
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN WELSH

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row, Chelsea Thursday ([21 or 28] October 1858).
docBody.p: My dear John,—It would seem we have got very very far away from ‘the golden age’ to judge by the embarrassment people feel, and the roundabout dialect they adopt whenever there is question of money, between even those most nearly connected.
Will you permit me to revive the golden age for a moment, and say what I have to say kurt und gut [short and good]; having never been able to develop a talent for roundabout in my life!

You have plans to make for the winter—must do something to prevent this tendency going further.John Welsh had tuberculosis. In making your plans; will you bear in mind that Mr. C has fifty pounds ready, to pay your journey to Madeira and back, or to any other foreign place you choose to go to.John Welsh accepted the gift, from Lady Harriet Ashburton’s bequest to TC (see TC to JWC, 18 Aug.); on the advice of Dr. Henry Bence Jones, he and his mother went to stay in Falmouth, Cornwall, where he was befriended by the Quaker sisters Anna Maria and Caroline Fox; Caroline later reported TC’s words of gratitude when she visited him at Lady Louisa Ashburton’s villa in Mentone, 5 March 1867: “I have always … a sort of pious feeling about Falmouth and about you all, and so had she who is gone away from me, for all your kindness to John Welsh; you couldn’t do a greater kindness than all you did for him and his mother“ (Caroline Fox, Memories of Old Friends; Being Extracts from the Journals and Letters of Caroline Fox … from 1835 to 1871, ed. H. N. Pym [1882] 340).
This money has as it were dropt to him out of the moon! to give away not to keep—so that you can use it without the slightest fear of inconveniencing him, or even being under any obligation to him.
I should be heartily glad to know you had determined on something feasible.
I feel the changes of temperature here dreadfully. If that man were not such a great helpless Baby, I would go to Madeira or elsewhere with you myself.
Don’t trouble yourself to answer this note. The best and most desired answer will be to come shortly, and tell me you will employ that fifty pounds for the purpose specified.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S [LST], [late Oct.]. MS: Duke. Quot: Ashton 402–3, 408. Dated about a month after TC’s return from Germany, 22 Sept., and JWC’s return from Scotland, 29 Sept., and before GEJ to JWC, 28 Oct. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 23 October 1858.]
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: I begin to think myself the victim-character of a Farce,—the ‘Madame Torson’Untraced. whom everybody has conspired to persuade of something against the evidence of her senses!

It is now more than a month that Mr Carlyle has been here, in his own house, palpable, ‘before my eyes,’ and also very palpable to my ears! and still the first question of all my acquaintance is; “how is Mr C getting on in Germany?“ or, “Does he go into Silesia before his return“? or “when did you hear from Mr C?“ or something to the effect that I am under a hallucination in believing my Husband beside me, or the man that is beside me my Husband!— He was in Germany during the first three weeks of September; but put off no time he could help, in a country destitute of “Christian Beds“ and anything in the shape of “human food“! Ten days of the three weeks he passed in a Calypso Island (of Rügen), where Madame von Usedom spirited him away in a carriage and four, and where, (the Calypso being scotch), a
certain approximation to Christianity in the Beds and humanity in the food appears to have been attainable. The other eleven days he was rushing from Battlefield to Battlefield, like a man chased by Devils! And arrived here in a condition that reminded one of Cruiser after his fight with Rarey!John Solomon Rarey (1827–66), horse trainer from Groveport, Ohio, had recently tamed a particularly vicious horse called Cruiser, owned by the earl of Dorchester, who gave him the horse. On 28 June Rarey showed the tamed horse to Queen Victoria. Cruiser apparently reverted to his untamed ways after Rarey’s death.

As for me, whom you kindly ask about; I continued in a horrid way, till Miss Baring persuaded me away to Bay House (opposite the Isle of Wight) where in twenty four hours I became all healed—like a cracked china basin boiled in sweet milk!!An old method of mending a broken dish was to fit the pieces together, tie them in place with string, and boil them for two to three hours in sweet milk. They were kind as the Angels to me; and the place a Paradise! comparatively. I staid three weeks; then on the strength of my regained capabilities I went to Dumfrieshires (over the border) and staid there five weeks—getting myself “made of“Coterie speech. which always agrees with my constitution. So that I returned, to fodder Cruiser,I.e., to look after TC. in a state more up to the undertaking.Thomas Woolner wrote to Emily Tennyson, 22 Oct., that JWC looked better in health but “more sad than I think I ever saw her before, in fact it made me feel quite sad to see her“ (Woolner 153).

What do you think of that marriage?Presumably the engagement of Lord Ashburton and Louisa Stewart-Mackenzie; they were married 17 Nov. Oh dear Oh dear! The most brilliant of women are missed no longer than the most insignificant! If he had only married a natural, good hearted, unpretending woman, who would have looked up to him, instead of a Brummagen edition of the same thing!— Lady Sandwich takes it beautifully “prepared to adopt as a Daughter any one who will make dear Ashburton happier.“ She told me Lord A had written “such a kind letter about his marriage to Mrs Frances Baring“!— But I can’t see how he could make a kind letter out of it to her; unless in promising that he would have only a daughter! at worst!Hortense Eugenie Claire m., 1832, Lord Ashburton’s younger brother, Francis Baring. Lord Ashburton’s only son, Alexander Montagu, had d. in infancy. Lord Ashburton and Louisa Stewart-Mackenzie were to have one da., so the title passed to Francis.
When are you coming to London?
Oh—the light books! I had nearly quite forgot
I know of only one new novel readable

p.note: Holme Lee (pseud. of Harriet Parr), Sylvan Holt’s Daughter, 3 vols. (1858), reviewed by Geraldine Jewsbury in the Athenaeum, 13 Nov.

docBody.p: But I will keep my letter open till Geraldine Jewsbury come over—who being the Reviewer of novels for the Athenaeum ought to have some decent ones at her finger ends
No good novel, for the moment but these are readable G. says

Eva Desmond
Frampton Hall
One and Twenty
Guy LivingstoneEva Desmond, Eva Desmond, or Mutation, 8 vols. (1858), reviewed by Jewsbury 18 Sept.; Frances J. Wedgwood, Framleigh Hall: A Novel, 3 vols. (1858), reviewed by Jewsbury 21 Aug.; Frederick W. Robinson, One-and-Twenty, 3 vols. (1858), reviewed by Jewsbury 15 May; George A. Lawrence, Guy Livingstone, or Thorough (1857), reviewed by Jewsbury 1 Aug. 1857.

p.name: Jane W Carlyle
p.note: Jewsbury apparently left a MS for JWC to read on this visit as she wrote to JWC, 28 Oct.: “[I]f you have read the M. S. I will have it back please—will it do? How it is upon my honour I don’t know! … What a pen!“ The MS was probably an article (unidentified; probably not the review of Sylvan Holt’s Daughter) rather than her novel Right or Wrong (1859), 2 vols. She had been paid for that in Sept. by Hurst & Blackett and presumably it was being typeset, as it came out Jan. 1859.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A [LOA], 25 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 482.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Your grand and unexpected news,His engagement. you need not doubt, is abundantly interesting here; nor, in its suddenness, and escorted by its echoes in one’s memory, could it be otherwise than welcome and of glad omen. “Life belongs to the Living,“ says a wise man; “and he that lives must be prepared for changes.“Commonly attributed to Goethe; see also “Novalis,“ Works 27:17.

No friend of yours but must have seen with sorrow, little as you complained about it yourself, how in this late time your existence had become such a desert to you in comparison; not a solitude only but, as it were, a desert:—some remedy much needed surely, could remedy be found. And now, beyond
our expectation, here in some fair likelihood it is; a New Era actually rising for you, which may bring the future tense into some similarity to the past; and be a great improvement indeed!—

I have had the honour to see that amiable Lady more than once;See 33:83TC to LOA, 15 Sept. 1857. nor has rumour been silent about her many qualities: she is very good to remember me on such an occasion. I beg you to offer her my homages, my congratulations; none can wish more cordially a prosperous and noble course to her under the name she will now bear. For her own sake, and yours, and that of many others, such may well be a general prayer.

I called twice at Bath House,Lord Ashburton’s London home. on some false prophecy of you there. As matters have turned out, we will not lament the prophet’s downbreak; on such terms it is worth while to wait a little. I will say only: May a blessing be on this new Epoch of Your Life; and may nothing but good (or if that is too much to hope in terrestrial things,—may a conspicuous overplus of good) follow from it to everybody!

closer.salute: I am and remain / Yours always truly /

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 26 Oct. MS: NLS 516.60. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: In great haste I send you today 1/6 worth of Stamps for the Carriage of that Book: a clear debt whh I have felt lying on me for some time. The charges of Carriage were all strictly ordered to be franked;—and the blockheadsChapman & Hall. entrusted have managed that like the other parts of “the sending“ whh they took in hand. To Germany, the distance of whh is hardly four days, I have no reason to understand that one of the Copies has yet got, tho’ despatched a month ago: inquiring into the Canada Pair of Copies, I found they had been sent by some “Parcels Company“ (of uncertain speed and punctuality), at the easy rate of 23/6 for the two,—the charge by post being all the while abt 8 / or 10 /!— In short I am quite in a passion with the blockheads,—and will not say another word upon them.

Last Saturday night your James was again here; looks quietly well; by every appearance, doing well, and taking root in his new place.See TC to JCA, 13 Oct. He was about seeking out some Lodging of his own,—in better air, higher up, about 1½
mile from his Office, for the sake of exercise daily. Islington quarter hits all these conditions; and there he had heard of something likely;—will, no doubt, succeed after a little search.

Jane keeps up her heart wonderfully; very much improved by her Scotch trip: I only fear the coming winter colds;—but she must of course take every precaution. Her Cousin,John Welsh. the young man whom you heard me speak of to Miss Welsh,In Aug., to JWC’s aunt Ann Welsh; see TC to JWC, 6 Aug. seems clearly (to us) to be affected in the lungs; and we are very anxious to see him off to Madeira, in time; which indeed is too probably a terribly indispensable matter to the good young man! He is very clever in his sphere,John Welsh was a meteorologist. and very honest; evidently rising in esteem with those about him: but this is a sad item in his outfit for the world.

Of the Doctor I by no means see so much as I want: I believe he does not like to bother me with his Watts &c; were the eldest ladTom Watt. fairly off on a “new voyage“ (say in a month hence) he will probably be more accessible to me.
I know not whether you are in MoffatProbably visiting the spa at Moffat Well. at prest, or returned, or only still going: I fancy a week of that kind will do you good in various ways.
Enough, dear Sister: I must end as usual
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF [JFE], 27 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 10455. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FERGUS

docBody.p:
About a week ago, there arrived here a Box, with shipping marks upon it, and a strong smell of intoxicating liquor about it;—which contained, when opened, 20 Bottles, and had once contained 24, of excellent Scotch Whiskey. No mark or indication was discoverable from whom this beneficent Article proceeded: but I said at once, “Aut Fergusius aut Diabolus [Either Fergus or the Devil]!—to which the female intellect, tho’ disposed to raise doubts, could not but incline assent. Happily, at an after stage, there was discerned the Excise Permit, with a definite name on it, one Paterson of Dunfermline’s;George Paterson, grocer and dealer in spirits, 17 Bridge St., Dunfermline. who, application being made to him, pleads guilty; so that the matter is now certain. I can only say, Many thanks for your kind remembrance of me, when you have so much else to remember! There is something very beneficent in
the little action; for which I am truly grateful (in this bad world, now growing so solitary to one too), and will have a pleasant memory of you,—nay shall, whether I will or not, till the liquor is all slowly spent, at least. Our old stock was not quite out, tho’ verging that way: of the new I have made my Wife even take a thimbleful, twice over, by way of close to the Day, and each time it has brought her a good sleep,—could one but hope it would hold on at that rate.

Paterson declines the high honour I had offered him of replacing the 4 Bottles spilt by his carelessness: but he may depend upon it, the blame is his; I have had of bottles perhaps 300 or 400 sent from Leith precisely in the same way; and of these there was never any broken before, except once simply one, and this the Wine-merchant instantly made good, with apologies. The mind trusts that Paterson is not yet paid!— On the whole, once more, many hearty thanks; and as the Proverb says, “May never waur be among us!“—

I came home from Germany about a month ago; a totally broken man. Never was such lodging offered to a thinskinned mortal; never such food; and we went witht resting, at the top of our speed, in railways full of tobacco for 31 days. The Riesengebirge, the Sächsische Schweitz [Saxon Switzerland], I found very beautiful,See Works 17:52–55. Leith wine-merchant: Hutchison & Co.—if I had been at all in quest of “beauty.“ I wished to see 13 different places, none of them beautiful, and escape home with my life.— — I have got back my Horse (not in the powerfullest condition), and am endeavouring to get into motion again, if I could. A bit of terribly rough way I still have, if I continue living; but after that, I lie down, and honestly do nothing for the rest of my life. Let us hope Dizzy will bring you back soon,Parliament had been prorogued 2 Aug. and was not recalled until 3 Feb. 1859; as an M.P., Fergus would not have been in London during the parliamentary recess. Disraeli, as chancellor of the exchequer, would not have been responsible for recalling Parliament. & in good case. Yours ever truly T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LS], 28 Oct. MS: NLS 19.3.52.7. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: I find the Wife here will come to you on Sunday Evg; it is “according to her promise,“ she says. Nothing remains for us, therefore, but to revoke my rash negative; and say that both of us will be ready when your carriage shall please to arrive that evening,—10 minutes past 7, as we shall guess it to be (dinnerat ¼ to 8);—and you need not write farther, if this is all right.
This change to warmth of atmosphere again will perhaps do you good; wait only till the rain dry away!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF [JFE], 28 Oct. MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FERGUS

docBody.p: One bounty follows another; there appears to be no end of some people’s goodness! Scarcely was the Missive about the Whiskey got under way, when a new Shippers Wagon appeared in this astonished Street; and disembarked from it two huge Barrels,—which stand now safe down stairs, and were found to contain solid provision, as the former package had done liquid,—ample stock of Fife Potatoes, namely, and a sack of do new oatmeal. The taste of these articles, I do think, will be pleasant and salutary both to soul and body!— In sober prose truth, we feel all this to be very kind; and are much gratified by such remembrance from an old friend. In my own name and that of another, I am to send you many thanks again,—as if that were some kind of payment.

London is fast filling again with its motley populations: the weather is sometimes sharp, sometimes again dirty (as today); but oftenest beautiful, with its pale sunshine amid the red leaves, in a world all fallen silent;—beautiful, tho’ earnest nearly sad; like a serene old-age among us mortals.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 28 Oct. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 28 Oct. 1858. MS: NLS 552.177. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Here is Magnus’s Empfangsschein [receipt];Presumably for portraits and engravings ordered from Eduard Magnus in Berlin; he had previously helped TC in his search for portraits of Frederick; see 30:147–49 and 33:211TC to EMA, 29 Dec. 1855, and TC to WWV, 22 April. whh you may read & burn.

I have been looking over your old museum Tickets, Excerpts &c; and
reading Preuss’s Thronbesteigung [Accession to the throne]Probably Johann David Erdmann Preuss, Friedrichs des Grossen Jugend und Thronbesteigung: Eine Jubelschrift (Berlin, 1840). (a dreary hollow chaunt of pretended psalmody, thro’ one of the least musical of human throats,—ach Gott!)—and find myself sadly destitute of authentic, physiognomic particulars, or precise records about all that. Some more Books abt these affairs, all along from 1740 to 1756 (baddish Books, if good there are not) I ought to have: how cheap were £20, were £40, if it could essentially help me on that score! English Books, Prussn, French abt those 2 Silesian wars:—I wish you wd consult with yr learned neighbour,Newberg’s German neighbor; see TC to JN, 11 Oct. with yourself, and see whether there is nothing farther possible.— In the Museum I think is some “History of Kaiser Karl VI“For Kaiser Karl VI (1685–1740), Holy Roman emperor, 1711–40, see Works 12:311; for TC’s account of his death, see Works 14:388–91. (please see if there is not a real acct of his death there;—at any rate, get me the Ticket for it). Then there is Adelung, Staats-Geschichte (and other horrid compilatns):Johann Christoph Adelung, Pragmatische Staatsgeschichte Europens von dem Ableben Kaiser Carls 6 an bis auf die gegenwärtigen Zeiten, 9 vols. Gotha, (1762–67); TC had 8 vols.: HCC. look into these a little; vote Whether one ought not to make an effort towards buying them? Surely there must be some English Narrative abt Carthagena,For the events at Carthagena, see Works 15:186–93. abt that Spanish War, abt &c &c:—I fear, not, however! Nothing but Pamphlets and unauthentic rubbish.

Does Dickens,Melchior Guy Dickens (ca. 1696–1768), sec. to Brig. Gen. Charles Dubourgay, British minister to Berlin, 1728–1730; see Works 13:230–31. in his Despatches, say nothing about “the Accession“ in its outward phenomena? I am reduced to BielfeldJacob Friedrich von Bielfeld, Lettres familières et autres, 2 vols. (Leide, 1767); TC’s copy (HCC) is autographed: “T. Carlyle, Chelsea, 1856 (from A. Gilchrist)“; TC described this collection of letters about Frederick as “an afterthought, composed from vague memory and imagination. … Not to be cited ‘freely’ at all, but sparingly and under conditions. They abound in small errors, in misdates, mistakes; small fictions even, and impossible pretensions:—foolish mortal, to write down his bit of knowledge in that form!“ (Works, 14:232). and the intolerable psalmody of Preuss!— Look some day for that Kaiser’s death at any rate (they say it was an indigestion, and he wd not believe himself dying, &c) “20 octr, 1740, 1–2 a.m.“— The English Newspapers at least are discoverable: but perhaps they are even worse than Preuss! Tho’ far from roadworthy, I want to be upon the road again. Sun is not high at this one’s season of the year and afternoon!—
We are to be out on Sunday night coming;Dining with Lady Sandwich; see TC to Lady SLS, 28 Oct. Sunday following that, not out, but will hope to see you here.
With TicketCall slip for British Museum Lib. (of Kaiser Karl, Adelung &c) I could perhaps go myself some day.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [30 Oct.]. Addr: Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 1 Nov. 1858. MS: NLS 606.515. Pbd: Froude, LM 2:388–90 inc. Quot: Ashton 408; Fielding and Sorensen 237–38.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! I feel so fractious this evening!—Should like to break something or box somebodys ears! Perhaps it is the east wind—perhaps my dinner of only soup—perhaps original sin! whatever it is; I must positively try to come out of it! and the best way I can think of to smooth my “raven down“John Milton, Comus lines 250–51; see also 20:7JWC to TC, [1 Oct. 1845]. is writing some lines to you.

Your last letter was charming Dear! Just the sort of letter one wants from a place familiar and dear to one! all about every thing and everybody. Since I knew Mrs Pringle I have come to understand and enter into the late Lady Ashburtons terror and horror of what she called “all about feelings.“Coterie speech; see 24:148JWC to TC, [26 July 1849].—Speaking of her; a piece of news came to us the other day that I have not recovered the shock of yet! Lady Sandwich came to call, and handing me an open letter said. “Read that. I thought you would like best to hear it from me.“ The letter was in Lord Ashburton’s handwriting—and the first words that caught my eye were “I have proposed to Miss Stewart McKenzie and she has accepted me“!— No doubt of that if she had the chance! Louisa McKenzie has been on the look out for a great match these ten years.Louisa Stewart-Mackenzie had been in love with William Stirling of Keir, later Stirling-Maxwell (1818–78; ODNB), and had been courted by Sir Edwin Landseer (1802–73; ODNB); see 33:83TC to LOA, 15 Sept. 1857. In Sept. 1859, Edward Stanley wrote to his wife: “Lady Ashburton keeps writing to Landseer pressing him to go there which is odd considering that she threw him over to marry Ashburton, being all but engaged to him“ (Nancy Mitford, The Stanleys of Alderley [1939] 269). She was notoriously “setting her cap“ at Lord A six weeks after his wife’s death. He is very trusting and has been very lonely—like a child that had lost its mother—in a wood! Carlyle said from the first “I dont think Lord Ashburton will ever marry again; but I wont answer for his not letting himself be married!“ In whatever way the thing have come about there it is! a fact! and the marriage will take place as soon as the Trouseau and Settlements can be got ready. I
shall never like the new Lady Ashburton—that I am sure of!Thomas Erskine wrote to Louisa Stewart-MacKenzie, 2 Nov.: “You will probably see a good deal of my excellent friend Carlyle—who is much to be loved and from whom much is to be learned. … I also love Mrs Carlyle—& would hope that you may love her too.— She will reward all true kindness—all true heartedness—I say this, because she is not so popular as Mr Carlyle“ (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). She is full of affectation, and pretension if not pretence! Lady Sandwich looks at this speedy replacing of her daughter from a quite practical point of view, and is “prepared to adopt Miss Mc as a daughter“ “If she (the new wife) make Ashburton happier that is all she (Lady S) must think of!“— Louisa McKenzie who never saw Lady S has written asking for “her love“ and blessing and so forth! And it is all going on in a paradisiacal fashion for the present!

Tomorrow we dine at Lady S’s, with Lord A, just arrived from the place in the northPresumably Kinlochluichart; Louisa Stewart-Mackenzie’s father had an estate 20 mi. away; see 33:83TC to LOA, 15 Sept. 1857. where he has perpetrated this piece of rashness. It makes me sick to see how soon the most admired and adored woman gets her place filled up!Lady Harriet Ashburton had d. 4 May 1857. He (Lord A) says, poor man, in the letter he wrote to tell Mr C of the marriage, that “lonely as he felt, he would not have married again if he had not found another of the same high nature“! That aggravated me more than anything!—
Well! you cant be expected to care to read so much about a marriage of which you know neither party—

My cousin John (George’s Son) was here again the other day, and I never felt so hopeless about him— His countenance, his voice, manner, everything about him is changed. And yet Bence Jones tells him it will be time enough if he get to a warm climate before the spring winds set in— He will never go, I believe, if he wait till Spring!

I am going to Richmond the first possible day to talk to his mother— She is the strangest woman—always trying to hide her son’s danger as if it were a crime. The fatalest symptom I see in him is the sanguineness about his recovery, and the irritability on the subject of his health which have taken place of the depression he manifested in Summer; while his state gives no reason for the change of mood—on the contrary his cough, and expectoration, are greatly increased and so, he owns, are his night-perspirations. He is paler and thinner—and from being the shiest, most silent of men he now talks incessantly and excitedly—and in this state he goes about, doing his usual work—and he left here the other day after dusk!
I am very grieved about him. He is the only cousin I have that I have had any pride or pleasure in.
Upon my word I had better give up for this writing. Nothing to tell but grievances!

Well! here is one little fact that will amuse you! Just imagine, the bit of boiled ham which you would hardly let me have, has lasted, for my supper, up to last week!! and I never stinted myself only—I kept it “all to myself,“ like the greedy Boy of the story Book— I began to think it was going to be a nineteenth century miracle! But it did end at last and now I am fallen back upon porridge and milk! which is not so nice I dont know about Dr CopelandPossibly Dr. James Copland (1791–1870; ODNB), 5 Old Burlington St.; Scottish physician practicing in London who was a specialist in diseases of the lung and author of several works, his most famous being Dictionary of Practical Medicine, 3 vols. (1858).— I found him an old man— I am curious to know what will come of the Irish TutorThe new tutor for Janet Pringle’s boys (see JWC to JPJPR, [ca. 23 Nov.]); otherwise unidentified.— Love to the Dr
docBody.name: JC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, [30 Oct.]. MS: Eton Coll. Hitherto unpbd. Dated tentatively in late Oct., early in James Aitken’s stay in London.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—Your two Articles of Winter Comfort (“bosom-friends,“Possibly vests. we will call them) arrived yesterday; and are very nice and hopeful-looking. I have put them by till the grim of the winter come: we have beautiful weather for this week or two; but it cannot last,—indeed there are today symptoms of change for the worse.

I am busy as a bee,—stealing these half-minutes, while the Horse waits. I hope I am getting a thot better on; there is much need of it! But courage, courage!— We are both tolerably well; tho’ poor Jane went out yesterday, and almost caught a whiff of cold. Will take care again. No news otherwise at all.
I must just give you my thanks and my blessing.— Bid yr Boy Jim call agn;James Aitken had visited 23 Oct.; see TC to JCA, 26 Oct. he needs to be bidden; & I hardly ever have an instant.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JC, [early Nov.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Hitherto unpbd. Dated soon after the delivery of food from John Fergus, see TC to JFE, 28 Oct., and the Illustrated London News, 30 Oct. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 November 1858.]
div3.head: JWC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I was near screaming when I read Isabella’s note to Mr C and found you were cherishing ideas of sending meal and potatoes!— On no! For the love of god no more meal! no more potatoes! I went out for a drive the other day, and when I came home, there was hardly a possibility of getting in, for great casks in the passage, and men with flaring tallow-candles, trying vainly to move them! I thought we must have got the forty thieves barrelled up in this devoted house! You never saw such enormous casks! As to getting them down the kitchen stairs it was out of the question, so the assistantUnidentified. (called in from the neighbourhood) had to knock the tops off in the passage, empty them, then roll down the empty casks and fill in the contents—the casks being the only feasable place for keeping all those dreadful potatoes in! Oh I may well say dreadful, Jamie Dear; for as sure as I live these potatoes have the disease! and I know that in a short time they will have to be given to the pigs, and here one has no pigs! At all events the last thing on Earth that would be welcome to us just now is clearly potatoes—and meal! for at the top of one cask was a ‘bole’A boll: measure of oatmeal, about 140 lbs. of meal!!! I gave away the half of it, the first thing I did, to our next-door neighbourThe Gilchrists. who has little children that like porridge. But I have still more than we should consume ourselves in six years, and am looking out for other meritorious individuals to give some to.

Mr C dines so late at present (often not till seven of the evening) that he cant do with any supper. And I who dine like a Christian female at half after 2 have recently discovered that whisky toddy (good gracious!) and a biscuit is the best supper for a woman puzzled to get to sleep before four in the morning! You would laugh to see me measuring out my whisky in the sort of little glass thing the Drs use for measuring laudanum and prusic acid in! I am so afraid of increasing the doze! It is useful to me in the meanwhile really, but all that sort of thing loses its effect in longer or shorter time. I am not to be called an Invalid at present however, only a delicate woman who mustn’t take the least liberty with herself. I am never out of doors after sunset; so I might as well be living at “Craig o’ putta“ for any parties I get to! I do continue to go out in the forenoons tho’; having kept off colds hitherto and my friends are
very kind to me, in coming to see me at home tho I am “a Vetrinary Surgeon’s Daughter!“The Illustrated London News, 23 Oct., pbd. a memoir, “Thomas Carlyle,“ which included the misinformation that JWC was “the only daughter of a veterinary surgeon of good fortune, and a lineal descendant of the great reformer, John Knox.“— Do you know that was how you came to get the Illustrated news? It was sent here by the miserable blockhead who wrote the article,Unidentified; possibly Frederick Martin. and Mr C packed it up, and addressed it to you, and sent it immediately out of the house that I mightn’t get my eye on that piece of news about myself!—The Dr, my Cousin John Welsh, and all my acquaintance conspired to keep me ignorant of it—Considering very sensibly that the one stupid impertinence about my Father would move me a hundred times more than any amount of laudation of Mr C—whose praises one is really blasé upon! But Tait—the man of the PictureRobert Tait, who painted A Chelsea Interior.—the man who always does the flatsoled underbred thing took care to enlighten me at the earliest opportunity—and that offered itself today! He then tried to smooth me down by showing a letter that had been published in last weeks Illustrated news signed M.D. and professing to be from “a townsfellow of Miss Welsh’s“ (poor Miss Welsh what has she done to be so shown up?) now about Birmingham“M. D. Walsall“; John Burton was the only M.D. listed in Walsall in the Medical Directory for 1860; Burton (ca. 1806–81), b. Virginia, U.S.; graduated from Edinburgh Univ., 1826; coauthor with Robert Lorimer of Observations on the History and Treatment of Cholera Asphyxia, as it Has Appeared at Haddington (Edinburgh, 1832). In 1832 he was practicing in Kelso and Lorimer in Haddington; Robert Lorimer (1802–48), surgeon, was the eldest son of the Rev. Robert Lorimer (1765–1848), JWC’s minister in Haddington; see 1:203–4JBW to EA, [Early Oct. 1819]. Walsall, Staffordshire, is about 9 mi. NW of Birmingham.—who “could not suffer my Father to be so misrepresented“—and certainly his account of him showed a devoted admiration which had lasted a long time! If he had only stopt there but he proceeded to extoll my “charms of body and mind“ (as Miss Welsh of course) in terms that must make me the subject of infinite merriment I should say!M. D. wrote, 24 Oct.: “Miss Welsh was the daughter of Dr. John Welsh, of Haddington, N.B., a ‘gentleman every inch’, and one of the most highly cultivated and locally eminent medical men of his day in Scotland. … Miss Welsh was in her earliest years a most highly talented and cultivated lady, in whom there was the most rare and happy combination of the beauties of mind and person“ (Illustrated London News, 30 Oct.). The source for the information was probably Robert Lorimer, one of JWC’s contemporaries in Haddington (or, less probably, Burton’s wife, Anne, who was b. in Haddington), rather than John Burton himself. When I told Mr C, he was very angry with Tait and told me that MartinPossibly Frederick Martin, working on the Illustrated London News as well as the Statesman as a subeditor. had come here to make excuses and had said that ever since that Paper appeared they had been perfectly bombarded with letters
extolling my Father and stating the fact about him—fifty letters had been received in one day! This comforts me—I care more about that testimony thus made to my Fathers memory and after so many many years by so many who knew him, than about having been introduced as a Vetrinary Surgeon’s Daughter to the General Public!— So good night—kind regards to Isabella
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-Mr. W [MWA], 1 Nov. Addr: Mssr. Chapman & Hall / 193 Piccadilly. MS: Berg. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MR. WARREN

docBody.p: On the opposite page is a mem. which I will thank you to despatch at once to that egregious Agent you have in Edinr!John Menzies; see TC to JMJME, 1 Nov. Neither of those copies is yet come, so far as I can learn; one of them I expressly hear is not.— I must say I never saw or heard of worse carrying-trade than has been on this occasion: £1.3.6 to Canada (price by Post being about 10 / ), with no certainty when or whether ever the Parcels will be delivered:—that is but one item; emblematic of many others in the affair:—I wish we had at once despatched every Copy by the Post; that, at least I could myself have done!— Please send off to Menzies at once, and deliver me from hearing more of this affair.

I also want to see, in good time,—directly if there is no reason for delay,—the Engraver of Frontispiece to Vol II.The engraver of Fredericus Wilhelmus, “from an engraving after A. Pesne,“ is unidentified; see Works 13:frontispiece; see also TC to EC, 12 Oct.— His Picture appears to me a disgrace to human nature, in its present state,—a pretty exact portrait of the clothes in his original, and as to the man, no more like him than it is to the Emperor of Japan;—an Engraving calculated only to please an extremely juvenile class of mortals! Pray send him, and lets try if we cannot put some one slight feature of Friedh Wilhelm into it.—
Please do these things; you need not answer otherwise.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JM [JME], 1 Nov. MS: Hilles. Pbd: Notes and Queries, 12th ser. 7 (18 Sept. 1920): 230, and, in a slightly different version, 12th ser. 9 (30 July 1921): 88.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN MENZIES

docBody.p: Mem. For Mr Menzies, EdinrSee TC to Mr. WMWA, 1 Nov.

2 Copies of Carlyle’s Frederick, to the respective Addresses:
1O “Mrs Austin, The Gill, Cummertrees“ &c
and 2O “Mr Carlyle, Scotsbrig, Ecclefechan“:—

Be so good as wrap them into one Parcel, addressed “Mr Carlyle Scotsbrig Ecclefechan“ (2d of the already given addresses); carry said Parcel across to the Caledonian Railway Station and despatch:—it will, once started, get to its place in four hours, after lying about 5 weeks in its present Quarters!
docBody.name: T. C.
docBody.p: Chelsea, 1 Novr, 1858

ps.p: N. b. If NO 2 is gone (whh I doubt), despatch NO 1 with its own address from same place;—and buy a Bradshaw or MurrayRailway timetables. for future use!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 2 Nov. MS: NLS 552.178. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Thanks for your Museum Excerpts and Tickets:Neuberg’s notes and British Museum Lib. call slips. there is nothing said about the poor Kaiser’s “indigestion of mushrooms,“Karl VI died from eating mushrooms; see Works 14:389. abt whh Bielfeld and others speak.

Your new straw-paper is not of first-rate quality:—here (what I am now writing on) is some of the old, old, or primeval sort; why, in Heaven’s name, did not they stick by that? There certainly was a “work of the Devil,“ driving men upon roads that cd lead to nothing,—or towards “cheap and nasty“ only, whh is a very bad goal for all parties concerned. If it be possible to procure some like this,—well. If not, continue your experiment upon the newest sort (whh the Excerpts are written upon); & endeavour to choose for the best. On Sunday Evg you may bring me yr selected specimen or specimens.

The Prussian BookDecker’s German edn. of Frederick (vol. 1), trans. Neuberg (Berlin, 1858). looks perfectly well; the paper excellent, tho’ thin; at least no bad Engravings to be dreaded!— At p.11, I have marked a superficial error, whh to some few in Deutschland, will be ugly: “The Devil in Harness“
comes from Hamlet,The quotation is not from Hamlet but from J. W. Goethe, Wilhelm Meister’s Apprenticeship bk. 5, chap. 11, trans. TC; see Works 23:359. and the “harness“ means man’s-armour not horse’s draught-tackle at all! It shd be “in (or im?) Harnisch.“ Goethe (Wilhm Meister, criticism &c on Hamlet) quotes “Der Teufel ist in (im?) Harnisch; hat uns alle in Furcht gejagt [The Devil is in harness; he has put us all in fright]“— Of course the Text is irremediable to you at present; but perhaps you had better make the change there, in Table of contents p.11, to shew critics that you are aware of the oversight. An extremely inconsiderable matter, after all! Yours sincerely / (in want of Paper, and much else) / T. Carlyle

div3.head: TC TO SIR EDWARD STRACHEY

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Edward Strachey , etc.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWP, 9 Nov. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO J. W. PARKER

docBody.p:
Mr Davis,Unidentified further. whom I have seen twice, and in whom I cannot but discern, tho’ under somewhat unfavourable circumstances, a vein of real sense and talent,—is writing a Paper, which, so soon as finished, he proposes to submit
to you for behoof of Fraser’s Magazine.Davis’s “Paper“ is untraced. Of course, I know not in the least whether it will suit you, or if it could be made to suit you; but I can gue[ss] there will probably be substantial matter in it, in one or the other form. He wishes me to indicate to you,—as I can honestly do,—that it may be worth some real inspection from you: which pray give it, when it comes before you. And that is the extent of my commission at present. I remain always
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p:
J. W. Parker Esq, Publisher
West Strand

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 13 Nov. MS: NLS 516.61. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I must insist on that 1/6! I was far from suspecting that you would suspect me of suspecting that you “grudged“ &c: but in fine the Book was meant to be franked, all the Gift Copies of it; and this one must be so, like the others. Mary, I find, has now got her Copy; some dud of a Bookseller at AnnanThere were three booksellers in Annan: William Cuthbertson and Wellwood Richardson, both in the High St., and Robert Watt in Murray St. had kept it lying for almost a month. Jenny also, in Canada, has got hers, and, we may hope, Sandy also.Janet Hanning and Alexander Carlyle; see TC to AC, 15 Oct. On the whole that petty affair, loaded with whatever blunders by the follies of surrounding mankind, may be considered done, as heavier portions of the business are.

I do not hear any more, and indeed have heard hitherto next to nothing but nonsense, as to “the popularity, the“ &c &c:Mazzini’s reaction was negative; he wrote to Emilie Hawkes, 3 Nov.: “I only had time to glance over Carlyle’s book and found it unredeemably bad and immoral. It is Feudalism, worship of force, intellectual and brutal. Friedrich Wilhelm the father, made into a hero. ‘C’est trop fort’ [it’s too strong]. Besides, as you noticed, the people does not exist for him; Kings, Margraffs and Burgraffs are all Humanity to him; any corporal drilling men is a remarkable phenomenon, etc.“ (Mazzini’s Letters to an English Family, ed. E. F. Richards [1922] 114). my next division of money will fall due a little earlier on account of it, and that is the one advantage it has (coupled with more drawbacks than appear at once) to a serious human soul.

I am praying daily I were begun to Part 2d: but as yet I shudder to engage again, and only keep poking about the outskirts, timidly skirmishing, or hardly even that. I have still a formidable two years ahead, if I live so long; and after that, I mean to work, at least hard work, no more, however long I
live. My scheme is, To get mainly away altogether out of this ineffable pluister, where there is less and less left that is helpful or delightful to me. I oftenest think of Scotland for a retreat, tho’ it is so far away,—too far indeed! I wish, however, James wd make practical computation, some time soon, as to that of a cottage (good & sizeable) on the Colvend shore:See TC to JWC, 28 July. grass for a horse &c;—and I always think some reasonable female creature might, with care and for honest recompense, be got, to keep the household in trim when one kindled it there. I have to say generally, There could not well any Son of Adam give a worse account as to Household Service in his time and country, than I here in the crown of the “New Era,“See Works 12:15–16.—more power to it!

Poor Jane took cold the other day; risked herself too far, making rearrangements in the House, poor little soul; and now this is the third morning she has to report herself, “Never slept at all.“ Alas, alas! It was all about hanging of a Picture here (Lord Ashbn had given her the Original of that “Little Drummer,“See JWC to TC, [27 July]. a truly beautiful big Picture,Elisabeth Cabot (mistakenly believing that Lord Ashburton had given the picture to TC rather than JWC) wrote to her sister Ellen Twisleton, 3 Dec., that it was “very handsome“ and “lordly“ of Lord Ashburton to give “Carlyle that picture, and I am very glad that C— should have such a pleasure daily, in his laborious, dreary life.“ Her husband, James Elliot Cabot, had been enjoying reading Frederick: “for he thinks what ever C’s defects are, as a historian & searcher after truth he ranks so far above any other writers“ (MS: Schlesinger A-99 Cabot Papers, folder 16). and it needed to be “hung“),—I almost wish it had gone down the river rather! But we will hope, we will hope some improvement soon.— Lord An is just about re-marrying. His Bride is Scotch, near 30 years his junr, no immense favourite of ours, and coming girt with very sorrowful memories: but it must be owned he had need of somebody to take charge of him. Adieu dear Sister. Yours ever T. Carlyle

We sometimes see James;Her son James Aitken. and hear always the best accounts of him,—as perhaps the Doctor will make you aware this day.— — I wish Symington wd keep his Book:Andrew James Symington (1825–98), Glasgow merchant, poet, biographer, and antiquary; presumably the book was his recent The Beautiful in Nature, Art, and Life (1857); he was a long-standing acquaintance of the Carlyle family. it is nothing but “a fluff of feathers“;Coterie speech; see 8:85TC to MAC, 25 March 1835. and one cannot quite handily write him that. It wd need to be good indeed if I cd go much into it just now. I will try for Bowie, sometime soon if I can find nothing.William Bowie (1824–86), Paisley weaver; see 12:19 and 21–22TC to MRI, [21 Jan. 1840], and TC to MAC, [23 Jan. 1840]. Presumably Jean Aitken had asked TC to do something for Bowie, otherwise unexplained. Symington had introduced Bowie to Jean; see 12:22TC to MAC, [23 Jan. 1840].

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 13 Nov. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: I suppose I had better come all the same,—tho’ it is clean against rule; indeed an evident sin I am led into! If you will be dressed at 6.30 precise (6.15 for 6.30), that will be my time for catching you at the foot of the stairs; and we shall have plenty of time still before the August FunctionaryUnidentified. make his appearance.
I grieve to report my poor Wife still not the least better this morning; worse rather (we may fancy), for it is the third night of no-sleep!

closer.salute: Yours ever truly (with kind regards to a certain LadyForster’s wife, Eliza. if she will accept them),

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JB [JBA], 22 Nov. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES BALLANTINE

docBody.p: It is with reluctance and regret that I have to refuse myself even this second easy honour which you are so kind as offer me!See TC to JBJBA, 11 Oct. I could say why, also;—but will beg you to believe that it is for any reason rather than for want of Scottish Patriotism, or of sensibility to your and the other Gentlemen’s kindness;Possibly John Gray and W. Bone, secs. to the Burns Festival, Ayr; see TC’s draft to WB and JGWBAJG, [22 Nov.?]. and so remain, as always,

closer.salute: Yours with many thanks & good wishes,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p:
James Ballantine Esq
&c &c

div3.sourceNote: TC’s Draft-WB and JG [WBAJG], [22 Nov.?]. MS: NLS 516.64. Hitherto unpbd. Dated tentatively with reference to TC’s refusal of James Ballantine’s invitation in connection to the Burns centenary celebrations; see TC to JBA, 22 Nov.
div3.head: TC TO W. BONE AND JOHN GRAY

docBody.p: Gentlemen,—I have received your Invitation to the Burns Festival;Ayr celebrated Burns centenary celebrations, 25 Jan. 1859, with processions, banquets, and prayers. and beg to express myself very sensible of the honour you do me.

It would have given me great pleasure to assist in any public testimony [“expression“ crossed out], as rational as the times permit, of the reverence [“feeling justly“ crossed out] entertained by Scotland towards this the most gifted of all her sons for some [“in these recent“ crossed out] generations past; one whom she has good right to look upon with pride, and alas also with many other feelings, wherein sorrow, self-reproach [‘pity, remorse’ crossed out] and determination to treat her next Gifted One a little more wisely, should not be wanting. [“To testify all this to one another and the world is not useless; but useful nor is the method to be quarrelled with, by Festival or such methods as the times permit“ crossed out]

Unfortunately, however, the state of my engagements threatens [“will“ crossed out] to detain me here [“in this part of the world“ crossed out] thro’ August; and I shall only be able to contribute to your Meeting my sympathies thanks and good wishes.
I have the honour to be [“With many thanks“ crossed out]

W. Bone &c, John GrayAccording to James Ballantine, the secs. were Mr. Bone and Mr. McNeight; see Chronicle of the Hundredth Birthday of Robert Burns (Edinburgh, 1859) 96. secretaries to the Burns Festival Ayr—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JP [JPR], [ca. 23 Nov.]. MS: Hilles. Pbd: Ritchie 322–25 inc. Dated approximately by JWC’s cold, which began after the hanging of The Little Drummer; see TC to JCA, 13 Nov.
div3.head: JWC TO JANET PRINGLE

docBody.p:
With a great effort I got up to breakfast this morning, the first time for a fortnight, having again my cold; and by the disheartening light of a London Fog, I perceived one letter on the table for me, black edged—which proved to be an announcement of your Uncle’s death!John Hunter d. 19 Nov., at Bennan, Tynron. His poor WifeCatherine Hunter. who seemed
so fond of him! I feel very sorry for her,—if my sorrow could but do her any good! which it can’t! I remember when I was there you considered his Life a precarious one; but he looked so hale and hearty,—was so full of kindness, and fun, and life, that day we dined with him,See JWC to CSCSO, [3 Sept.]. that the news of his death has shocked me more than my slight acquaintance with him seems to make natural.— Do write when you can find time, and tell me if his death was sudden, and what was his malady,According to the death cert., he had been ill for two years and d. of liver disease. and how his wife bears it. And, when you find a fit opportunity, give her my kind regards, and tell her I have a grateful remembrance of his and her kindness to me, and sincere sympathy with her affliction.— Oh Dear! what a comfortable, hospitable cheerful House BerminFor Bennan. looked to me that day! And what fun we made about “Aunt Kates“ puff-paste, and all that—and now—!

I have been expecting and wanting a letter from you. Plenty of people are kind to me here—very kind; but when one has found a place so good and pleasant for me as Tynron was, one likes to attach a thread (like little Tom Thumb) to the bushes along the road! in plain prose one likes to keep up ones relations with those who made it so pleasant.

I was agreeably astonished yesterday, to receive a call from Mary Hoggan!Mary Hoggan, a neighbor of Janet Pringle’s. She is really a nice creature; and it was like a glass of “Champagne“ to have her sitting here in my own room at 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea!

If you care to hear the last accounts of me “from an eye witness“ drive over to BellevueBellevue, Thornhill, home of Mary and her brother Edward Hoggan (1795–1867), Writer to the Signet and factor for the Waterside estate, nr. Thornhill. some day soon; for she was going home this week. From her I heard that the “new Tutor“The “Irish Tutor“; see JWC to MR, [30 Oct.]. was come to Lann, and was “a very gentlemanly young man“— So far so good!

It is rather vexatious, don’t you think, to have gone and laid myself up so early in the winter? It was Lord Ashburton’s Picture that was the innocent ostensible cause! I told you I think of the beautiful Picture of little Friz and his Sister Whilelmina which Lord A would give me,See JWC to TC, [27 July]. and which I had no place for in all my house, unless I removed the great Bookcase from the Drawingroom to the room below. It was sent on his return to London exactly at the wrong moment, when the weather had become intensely cold. At least at the wrong moment when there was a remarkably impatient Husband in the case! I would have let it stand on the parlour floor, for my part, until there was fitter weather for a household Earthquake. But every day Mr C suggested;
“My Dear when are you thinking of &c“ “Is the paper made yet for that wall?“ “Are you never going to &c“? till mortal patience could stand it no longer! and I sent for the CarpenterPossibly Parsons or Joseph Morgan; see TC to JWC, 14 July. and the paper hanger,Possibly John Walters, 22 Hasker St., Chelsea, or Oliver Osborn, 5 Bretton St., Chelsea. and the staircase window had to be taken out; and all the doors flying, and myself flying—to direct blockheads for a whole day. So at night I went to bed in a high fever—quite another sort of “fever“ from any you ever saw me in!—and for three successive nights I never closed my eyes, and was in agonies of face ach &c &c— And now I am shut up for six months I expect with my cough and all the rest of it. But the cough is not so bad as last year, and I have more strength to bear it. Thanks to Bay House and Lann Hall! Pity there is no sunshine in this world without shadow! That Picture is very charming to look at from my sofa; but such a cold is a heavy price for the pleasure!— I remember as if it were yesterday travelling all night in a post chaise with my Mother and an old East Lothian Farmer,Unidentified. who was going to meet my Father at Craigenputtoch, and advise about drains. My Mother and I were to be dropt at my Grand Fathers,Either her paternal grandfather, John Welsh (1757–1823), or her maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh (1752–1832); they had both lived in Nithsdale. I was mad with joy to go on my first journey, but oh so sick in a close carriage always! one minute I was chattering like a magpie, the next vomiting out of the window! In the course of the night I lay down at the bottom of the chaise, my head on my Mothers knees and whimpered and moaned. The old Farmer got tired of me—naturally—and said with a certain sharpness, words that cut into my small heart with a sudden mysterious horror! “Little girl,“ he said, “don’t you know that there is no pleasure to be had in this world without pain!“ No! I didn’t know it! But it was dreadful to hear for somehow I thought he who was old must be speaking truth. And I believed him, all in shrinking from him as a sort of cruel ogre! That was my initiation into the dark side of Life What was yours?
Now good night— Love to the BoysHer three sons; see JWC to CSCSO, [29 Aug.]. Is the nursemaidUnidentified. gone to fulfill her Destiny?
docBody.name: Jane C Welsh—

ps.p: Oh! I mean Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [ca. 25 Nov.]. MS: NLS 606.518. Hitherto unpbd. Dated about a fortnight after the beginning of JWC’s cold (around 10 Nov.), and after the Ashburton marriage (17 Nov.).
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
You darling Woman! Thanks! and a dozen kisses! It is so pretty, and soft, and warm! and above all it is the very thing I was wanting! something to keep my head from the cold without making a ‘fright’ of me!— For alas my Dear! I am in the depths of ‘Cold’ again, since yesterday gone a fortnight!— That “Picture,“ I foresaw how it would be! The House Earth-quake it would occasion would be the death of me! (figuratively speaking, let us hope!) When it arrived I had it peaceably set down on the floor of the parlour down stairs—promulgating my rational intention of leaving it there; till the weather should be more favourable for the shifting of our largest bookcase, containing some six hundred books, and for getting the wall behind it papered, preparatory to hanging up the Picture in the Drawingroom— But I was mad to hope that Mr Carlyle could ever by possibility be patient! Every day it was “My Dear, I am much afraid that Picture will get mischief down there!“ or “My Dear are you taking any steps yet about the paper for that wall?“ or “My Dear I dont see what harm the Carpenter removing that Bookcase could do to you!“—or “My Dear something else to the same tune! till in desperation, I sent for the Carpenters and set them to work. But, as I expected, they could not do their own work without superintendence— No London workman has a particle of ‘shift’ in him. So when they had got the bookcase, which was only in two parts, stuck fast in the staircase—with every appearance of its sticking there till the end of the world, or at least till the end of the house I had to go and stand over them on the coldest day of the year, and make them take out the staircase window, and show them how to get the heavy big thing out there, and in again by the back door.
